Hi there, our videos follow the Cambridge IGCSE Biology Paper 0610 syllabus.   You might be referring to the Cambridge O Level Biology Syllabus for Paper 5090.  The syllabi for Cambridge O Level Biology (5090) and IGCSE Biology (0610) are similar but not identical.   To get a detailed comparison, please visit these links to compare the two syllabi:  Biology O Level 5090 Syllabus: https://www.cambridgeinternational.org/Images/595450-2023-2025-syllabus.pdf  Biology IGCSE 0610 Syllabus: https://www.cambridgeinternational.org/Images/595426-2023-2025-syllabus.pdf
O level biology 5090 is a-bit more in detail whereas the IGCSE biology has a bit less detail in it and yeah you can see these videos for a more generalised revision.
Thank you miss.

Summary & Additional Notes: Classification goes from Kingdom -> Phylum -> Class -> Order -> Family -> Genus -> Species. There are 5 kingdoms: Animalia, Plantae, Fungi, Protista, and Prokaryote. (It is important to note that you should use the terms "Animalia" and "Plantae" in exams instead of animal and plant.)  Animalia is divided into Vertebrates and Invertebrates (=Arthropods) These are the classes of Animalia: Vertebrates: - Mammals - Birds - Fish - Reptiles - Amphibians  Arthropods: - Myriapods - Crustaceans - Insects - Arachnids  Plantae is divided into Ferns and Flowering Plants Flowering Plants are divided into Monocotyledon and Dicotyledon  (It is important to be able to know the different characteristics of different groups)  Characteristics of living organisms full definitions: - Movement: Ability to change position or location, locomotion  - Respiration: Chemical process of breaking down glucose in the presence of oxygen in the mitochondria of cells for metabolic activities - Sensitivity: Ability to detect and respond to changes in external environment (stimuli) - Growth: Permanent increase in dry mass and size - Reproduction: Production of an offspring of the same kind - Excretion: Removal of metabolic waste products and substances in excess of body requirements - Nutrition: Taking in of food and converting them into energy for growth and development

Yes, animal cells sometimes have vacuoles, but they are small and less prominent compared to the large central vacuole in plant cells. They are often not mentioned because their role in animal cells is less significant.

@IGCSEStudyBuddy   So the teacher asked what is the difference between animal cell and plant cell in terms of nucleus and vacuole. Am I wrong to say vacuole is not present in animal cell and is present in plant cell? Also what will be the difference in nucleus?

@user-uc4eo7gn4p  You may say that the plant cell has a large, permanent, central vacuole while an animal cell does not have this. The nuclei in animal cells and plant cells are fundamentally similar in structure and function.

Studying this the day b4 the bio exam 😢😢😢😢

This video explains the characteristics and classification of living organisms, including the five kingdoms, vertebrates, and invertebrates, as well as the binomial system of naming species and the use of dichotomous keys for identification.  [00:00] This video summarizes the characteristics and classification of living organisms according to the Cambridge IGCSE syllabus - Biology is the study of living things with seven characteristics that define them - Mrs Gren is a mnemonic to remember the seven characteristics of living things - Classification systems group organisms that can reproduce to produce fertile offspring  [02:41] Classification is the process of grouping organisms based on shared features - Binomial system is an internationally agreed system for naming species using genus and species - Dichotomous keys are used to identify organisms based on a series of questions about their features - Classification allows the subdivision of living organisms into smaller groups based on shared features  [05:24] Classification systems aim to reflect evolutionary relationships between species - Traditionally, organisms were classified based on shared physical features - Advancements in technology allowed for DNA sequencing to be used for classification - The more similar the DNA base sequences, the more closely related the species - Living things are classified into five kingdoms: animals, plants, fungi, protists, and prokaryotes - Animals are multicellular, lack cell walls and chloroplasts, and obtain nutrition by eating other living things - Plants are multicellular, have cell walls made of cellulose, contain chloroplasts, and obtain nutrition through photosynthesis  [08:09] The five kingdoms of organisms are animal, plant, fungi, protist, and prokaryote - Plant cells have cell walls and chloroplasts - Fungi are usually multicellular, have nuclei, and cell walls not made of cellulose - Protists may have cell walls and chloroplasts, and some make their own food - Prokaryotes are often unicellular, have cell walls not made of cellulose, and no nucleus or mitochondria - Vertebrates and invertebrates are the two major groups within the animal kingdom  [10:51] Vertebrates are animals with a backbone, divided into mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, and fish - Mammals have fur or hair, feed young with milk, have four-chambered hearts, and different types of teeth - Birds have feathers, lay eggs with hard shells, have beaks, and wings instead of four limbs - Reptiles have scaly skin, lay eggs with rubbery shells, and include snakes, crocodiles, and turtles - Amphibians live on both land and water, have moist skin without scales, lay eggs in water, and include frogs and toads
